content.text: She notices that the handle of the spoon quickly becomes very hot
State why this observation supports the suggestion that the spoon is made of metal
Describe, in terms of its atoms, how thermal energy is transferred through a metal
The archaeologist suspects that the spoon is made of metal. She places it above a flame, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Fig. 1.1
The archaeologist hopes that, by determining its density, she will be able to identify metal
Describe a method for determining the density of the metal from which the spoon is made
An archaeologist digging at an ancient site discovers a spoon. The spoon is made of unidentified material
Calculate the weight of a \(250\mathrm{g}\) mass
State the name given to point P
Use the section of the graph where spring S obeys Hooke's law \((F = kx)\) to determine the spring constant \(k\) of the spring
The student plots a graph of the force \(F\) applied to the spring against the extension \(x\). Fig. 2.1 is the student's graph
At point P on the graph, the line begins to curve
The box and the mass are at rest
State the resultant force acting on the mass
The box is firmly attached, in a horizontal position, to the body of a racing car
As the car accelerates the spring stretches by \(2.0 \text{cm}\)
1. Using Fig. 2.1, determine the tension in the spring
tension =   .........
2. Calculate the acceleration of the mass produced by this tension
acceleration =   .........
Fig. 2.2 shows a mass of 0.12 kg resting on the bottom of a box
A spring that is identical to S connects the mass and one side of the box. Ignore friction between the mass and the box
A spring S is suspended from a clamp stand in a school laboratory
A student hangs various masses from the end of S and determines the extension \(x\) produce by each mass
Calculate the useful work done in lifting the crate
work done =   .........
the energy supplied to the motor in 4.0s,
the overall efficiency of the fork-lift truck in lifting the crate
efficiency =   .........
A motor drives a mechanism to lift the crate. The current in the motor is 25A. The motor is connected to a 75V battery
Calculate
Not all of the energy supplied is used usefully in lifting the crate
Suggest two mechanisms by which energy is wasted
Fig. 3.1 shows a fork-lift truck lifting a crate on to a high shelf in a warehouse
The fork-lift truck lifts a crate of weight \(640\mathrm{N}\) through a vertical distance of \(3.5\mathrm{m}\) in \(4.0\mathrm{s}\)
the gravitational potential energy gained by the model parachutist,
the minimum possible speed with which the model parachutist was launched
Calculate
In practice, the launch speed must be greater than the value calculated in (a)(ii)
Explain why
As the model parachutist returns to the ground, it loses gravitational potential energy
Explain what happens to this energy as the model parachutist falls through the air at constant speed
A child's toy launches a model parachutist of mass \(0.40\mathrm{kg}\) vertically upwards. The parachutist reaches a maximum height of \(8.5\mathrm{m}\)
A process releases energy inside the Sun and its temperature stays high
State the name of this process
Suggest how, by using a drum of a different shape, the gardener can reduce the quantity of water lost by evaporation
The gardener is told that, by painting the drum white, he can reduce the quantity of radiation absorbed and so reduce the rate of evaporation
Describe an experiment to show that black surfaces are better absorbers of radiation than white surfaces. You may include a diagram
A gardener stores water in a large, cylindrical metal drum. The drum is painted black and has no lid. On a bright, sunny day, the water evaporates quickly and the water level in the drum falls
The Sun is a large sphere of high temperature gas. An extremely large quantity of radiates from the Sun into space every second
Calculate the value for the specific heat capacity of sunflower oil obtained by the student
specific heat capacity =   .........
State and explain whether the value for the specific heat capacity obtained by the student is too large or too small
A student uses a 2400W electric kettle to obtain a value for the specific heat capacity of sunflower oil
Fig. 6.1 shows the apparatus
The student uses a measuring jug and pours \(1.5\mathrm{kg}\) of sunflower oil into the empty kettle. He uses a thermometer to measure the temperature of the oil
The kettle is switched on and left on for 50 s. The temperature of the oil increases by \(32^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The student assumes that all the electrical energy is transferred as thermal energy to the oil
The ray continues into the air
Calculate the angle between the normal and the path taken by the light after it leaves the block
the speed of light in this plastic,
the speed of light in air
The frequency of the light produced by this laser is \(3.8 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\) and its wavelength is \(5.3 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}\) (0.00053 mm)
Calculate
Explain why the ray does not change direction as it enters the plastic block
A ray of light from a laser passes from air into a clear, semi-circular, plastic block
shows the ray entering the block
The ray continues in the same direction and meets the middle of the opposite surface at an angle of \(40^{\circ}\) to the normal. The refractive index of the plastic is 1.5
On Fig. 8.4, draw the shape of the trace now seen on the screen
Suggest a device that uses a diode in this way
State and explain the effect on the lamp of inserting the diode into the circuit
An a.c. power supply is connected in series with a metal-filament lamp. A cathode-oscilloscope (c.r.o.) is in parallel with the lamp, as shown in Fig. 8.1
Fig. 8.2 is the trace seen on the c.r.o. screen
Fig. 8.1
A diode is inserted in the circuit, as shown in Fig. 8.3
Fig. 8.2
Fig. 8.3 Fig. 8.4
(b) There are energy losses in the transmission cables
Explain why the energy losses become greater when the length of the transmission cables is greater
Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of using transmission cables of greater cross-sectional area
The output voltage of the transformer is greater than the input voltage
Explain how a transformer produces this output voltage
The a.c. supply from a power station is connected to the primary coil of a transform secondary coil is connected to long-distance transmission cables
On Fig. 10.1, draw lines to show the pattern of the magnetic field due to the current
State the feature of the pattern of the magnetic field lines that indicates the strength of the magnetic field at particular points
The current in the solenoid produces a magnetic field
State and explain the effect on the magnetic field of increasing the resistance of the variable resistor
In the shaded region of Fig. 10.2, draw a possible path for the \(\alpha\) -particles in the magnetic field
State and explain the effect on this path of reversing the current in the coils
In a laboratory vacuum chamber, some current-carrying coils produce a very magnetic field near a source of \(\alpha\) -particles
Fig. 10.2 shows the arrangement
Fig. 10.1 shows a variable resistor (rheostat) and a solenoid (long coil) connected battery

background count-rate =   .........
at \(t = 10\) minutes,
count-rate due to sample =
at \(t = 19\) minutes
count-rate due to sample =
Use Fig. 11.1 to determine the count-rate due to the radioactive sample
Use the values obtained in **(b)** to estimate the half-life of the radioactive sample
half-life =   .........
In a laboratory at a nuclear power station, a radiation detector is connected to a computer. The readings recorded are displayed on the computer screen

The detector is switched on. Ten minutes later, at time \(t = 10\) minutes, a small sample of radioactive material is removed from a nuclear reactor and placed near to the detector. Readings are recorded for a further 40 minutes. Fig. 11.1 shows the display
